awd_abstract_narration:
Groups are fundamental mathematical objects that encode symmetries; for instance, those of a crystalline material.  They arise in many fields including geometry, arithmetic, and even mathematical physics. They provide a bridge between algebraic and geometric properties of a mathematical object.  The principal investigator will study problems that traverse this bridge in both directions, applying algebra to uncover geometric properties of low-dimensional spaces and using geometry to shed light on problems that appear to be strictly algebraic.  An important theme is the concept of cohomology, which roughly speaking measures high-dimensional holes that exist in both geometric and algebraic settings.

The principal investigator will study the topology of arithmetic groups, the mapping class group, and the automorphism groups of free groups.  The planned research has two parts.  In the first, the investigator will study duality properties of these groups, which will be used to perform a series of cohomological calculations.  In the second part, the investigator will study the topology and geometry of the Torelli group.  Foci of these projects include finiteness properties of the Torelli group, the theory of representation stability, and relationships with invariants of homology 3-spheres.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This grant supported the research of Andrew Putman concerning the interactions between topology and group theory. Topology is a branch of geometry that studies properties of a space that are unchanged by deformations. For instance, these deformations cannot tear the space into multiple pieces, so the number of pieces is such a property. More generally, since the 19th century topologists have studied the "homology" of a space, which is a measurement of the number of high-dimensional holes that a space has.

Group theory is the study of symmetries, interpreted broadly. It interacts with topology in many ways; for instance, if a space has many complicated symmetries than its topological properties are tightly constrained. What is more, it turns out that groups themselves often have interesting geometric and topological properties, at least when they are viewed from a sophisticated viewpoint.

In this report, three families of results will be highlighted.

  1. The first concerns "arithmetic groups", which very interesting groups that arise from constructions involving the natural numbers 1, 2, 3, and so on. One major result proved by the PI during this grant period concerns the homology of these arithmetic groups. With Jeremy Miller and Peter Patzt from Purdue, he studied an important 1976 conjecture of Ronnie Lee and Robert Szczarba about the homology of so-called ``congruence subgroups''. What they proved is that this conjecture is often false, and the homology of these groups is far richer than one would expect.
  2. The second concerns the moduli space of curves, which is a space parameterizing geometric structures on two-dimensional shapes. It has deep connections to many areas of mathematics and physics. Answering a long-standing question, he completely calculated the so-called "stable homology" of certain spaces built from these moduli spaces called the "moduli spaces of curves with level structures".
  3. The third concerns the Steinberg representation. Roughly speaking, this parameterizes coincidences between geometric configurations. It was first studied in the 1950's, and plays a major role in many topics in group theory. One of its basic properties is that it is irreducible, that is, cannot be decomposed into multiple pieces. This was established in the 1950's and 1960's, but only under very strong finiteness conditions. Though the Steinberg representation continued to be studied by many people, no progress has been made since then on removing these finiteness conditions (though they exclude many of the most interesting examples). With Andrew Snowden from the University of Michigan, the PI introduced new techniques for proving irreducibility of such representations and proved that the Steinberg representation is always irreducible.
